entry.title: SuccessFactors Time Tracking Integration Guide
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Sending Attendance Data to SuccessFactors
  • Understanding Timesheet Structure
  • The External Time Data Approach
  • Cross-Midnight Attendance - Date and Time Field Rules
  • Deleting Attendance in SuccessFactors
  • Sending Absence Data from SuccessFactors
  • Best Practices Summary

Introduction

Important Note of the author : Just because an API exists doesn't mean you should integrate with it. üôÇ Always use common sense, and if there's no documentation for your specific scenario, there's probably a good reason.

This guide shares knowledge I gained from integrating SuccessFactors Time Tracking with third-party systems. While this is considered an edge case, the lack of available documentation made me document my findings to help others avoid similar struggles.

Sending Attendance Data to SuccessFactors

Understanding Timesheet Structure

Attendance is recorded in the SuccessFactors timesheet with the following characteristics:

Every entry is logged:

Every change generates a new timesheet that replaces (and references) the old one. This creates an excellent audit trail within SuccessFactors. However, this complexity is why sending attendance data from SuccessFactors Time Sheet to other applications is a bit more difficult

The External Time Data Approach

You cannot directly generate timesheet entries from external systems. If you want to send attendances to the SuccessFactors Timesheet from a third-party system or from a terminal, the process works as follows.

  • POST an "External Time Data" record to SuccessFactors
  • The record is saved in the system
  • An import job processes the data (can be instant or scheduled - see SAP KB Article 2854180)
  • Either the data appears as an Employee Time Sheet Entry in the employee's timesheet or the validation error of the unimported external time data record appears in the time sheet as an admin alert

Posting Attendance to SuccessFactors

API Endpoint: POST "apiserverofyourdatacenter" + ExternalTimeData"

Request Body Example:

{

   "externalCode": "4545455",

   "startDate": "/Date(1759622400000)/",

   "userIdNav": {

      "__metadata": { "uri": "User('ABC')" }

   },

   "startTime": "PT3H0M0S",

   "endTime": "PT15H0M0S",

   "timeType": "1234"

}

And you will be able to create an external time data entity:

 

Important Validation Behavior

Critical: A successful API response does not guarantee successful timesheet entry.

Here's why:

You receive a positive HTTP response when the external time data record is created. The import job runs and applies timesheet validations.If validation fails (e.g., duplicate booking), the status changes from "New" to "Error". The integration has already received a positive response.

Error Detection Methods

Since the API response doesn't reflect validation errors, you must use:

  • Admin alerts for timesheet import failures
  • End-user notifications showing validation errors on their timesheet

Cross-Midnight Attendance - Date and Time Field Rules

The External Time Data entity has specific requirements for handling attendance that spans across calendar days:

Scenario

startDate

startTime

endDate

endTime

Same day attendance

Required

Required

Must NOT be provided

Required

Cross-midnight attendance

Required

Required

Required

Required

 

Key Principle I followed during the implementation  of the integration:

Provide endDate only if: startDate ‚â† endDate

Omit endDate if: the attendance ends on the same calendar day

Deleting Attendance in SuccessFactors

The Challenge: Since you cannot directly modify the timesheet, deleting attendance requires updating the External Time Data record with a deletion flag.

For the deletion process is used a PUT request.

API Endpoint: PUT  "apiserverofyourdatacenter + ExternalTimeData ('recordIdyouwanttodelete')"

Request Body Example:

{

    "externalCode": "recordIdyouwanttodelete",

    "userIdNav": {

        "__metadata": {

            "uri": "User('ABC')"

        }

    },

    "startDate": "/Date(1772082000000)/",

    "startTime": "PT06H00M00S",

    "endTime": "PT10H00M00S",

    "timeType": "123",

    "correctionScenario": "TIME_SHEET_AND_EXTERNAL_SYSTEM",

    "status": "NEW",

    "deleteExternalTime": true

}

Now the external time data record is updated, and the import job is triggered.

The import job reads the deleteExternalTime flag and the entry is deleted from the timesheet.

 

Sending Absence Data from SuccessFactors

While integrating attendance is a bit more complex, sending absences to another system is pretty straight forward. SuccessFactors provides an intelligent service that enables near-real-time absence data transmission to third-party applications.

Integration Architecture

The integration uses the following components:

  • Base Object: EmployeeTime
  • Business Rule: Filters when to trigger the intelligent service
  • Intelligent Service: "Employee Central: Employee Time Off"
  • Integration Center Job: Sends data to the third-party REST endpoint

 

Implementation Steps

Step 1: Configure Business Rule

Define a business rule on the EmployeeTime object to filter trigger conditions. In this example Rule only workflow-approved or auto-approved or cancelled absences are triggering the intelligent service.

Step 2: Set Up Intelligent Service

Use the "Employee Central: Employee Time Off" intelligent service.

Optional: The flow rule provides you with an additional possibility to filter.

I use the flows on Timing ‚Äúwhen event is published‚Äù to get the near realtime data transfer.

Step 3: Build Integration Center Job

Configure the job to be triggered by the intelligent service. The job can send:

  • The entire EmployeeTime record as a body
  • Or like in my case just the uuid of the record that has been changed. This largely depends on your entire integration architecture and there are reasons for both scenarios.

The data is transmitted to the REST endpoint of your third-party application.

Best Practices Summary

  • Always validate that your use case is supported before integrating
  • Implement proper error handling for async validation failures
  • Use admin alerts to monitor import job failures
  • Timestamps and time formats are just weird in SuccessFactors -  I guess we have to live with that üôÑ
  • Follow date/time rules carefully for cross-midnight scenarios.
  • Use the intelligent service for real-time absence data transmission
  • Test thoroughly in a sandbox environment before production deployment

entry.title: 04 SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Current HCM System Assessment and Outcomes
entry.content:
This blog outlines the key areas to focus on when analyzing the current state of your HCM system. A comprehensive current-state analysis is the foundation of a successful SAP SuccessFactors implementation, ensuring the transition is not merely a ‚Äúlift and shift‚Äù of legacy challenges into a new environment, but a thoughtful, strategic transformation that delivers long-term value.

In my previous post, I covered the objectives of Phase 0; this article continues the series by focusing on assessing the current HCM system.

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/01-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-phase-0-objectives/ba-p/14287328

We typically cover the following areas in the assessment, which vary by customer based on complexity and global presence.

  • Current HCM Modules and Systems
  • Future state role of the current HCM System
  • Customizations  and Pain Points
  • Integrations Assessment
  • Data Assessment

1. Current HCM System Modules in the landscape:

 Having info on which systems are currently "live" and which specific modules are active within each country. This identifies where local "point solutions" (like a local payroll provider) might be operating outside of your global Core HR system. This information is critical for SI to develop the right deployment strategy.

 Workforce Volume & Classification:

 Capture employee volume statistics for all categories and countries. This will help with the Data migration scope, effort, localization requirements, etc.

  • Active Employees: Full-time or part-time workers currently on payroll and working.
  • Inactive Employees: Individuals still "on the books" but not working (e.g., long-term disability, sabbatical, or maternity leave where the contract is still active).
  • Terminated Employees:
  • Pensioners: Former employees receiving retirement benefits directly through your HCM/Payroll system.
  • Contingents: Non-employee labor (1099s, agency workers, or independent contractors) who may need system access but aren't on your standard payroll.
  • Countries in scope: List down all countries in scope with employee volumes.

 

Country

Active Employees

Inactive (LOA/LTD)

Pensioners / Retirees

Contingent (Contractors)

Terminated Records

Total Global

22200

348

NA

7600

45000

 2. Future State Role of Current HCM:

Transitioning to SAP SuccessFactors is rarely a "flip of the switch" where the old system vanishes instantly. The role of your current HCM System (SAP S/4HANA HCM, PeopleSoft, SAP ERP HCM, Workday, Lawson, UKG..etc ) depends entirely on your specific future needs. Based on my experience, here is how your current HCM system typically functions once SAP SuccessFactors HCM becomes SOS for the Employee record.

  • Co-existence : 

This is the most common scenario for large enterprises. In a  Core Hybrid deployment, the systems coexist. SAP SuccessFactors HCM might act as the "System of Record" for Core HR, and talent management, while the  ERP continues to handle support payroll, Benefits, time ..etc .

  • Decommissioning: 

You will only fully decommission the current HCM system. This happens once all modules‚Äîincluding Payroll, Time Tracking, and Benefits‚Äîhave been successfully migrated to SAP SuccessFactors HCM. Even then, decommissioning usually takes 1‚Äì3 years to ensure all compliance and tax cycles are completed.

  • Read-Only System: 

During the first 12‚Äì24 months post-implementation, the legacy system often becomes "Read-Only." This allows HR and Audit teams to verify data integrity or look up historical records that weren't migrated to the cloud. You would typically disable "Write" access to prevent data discrepancies between the two systems.

  • Data Archival System: 

Not all historical data is migrated to SuccessFactors HCM . The legacy system‚Äîor a decommissioned version of its database‚Äîserves as the Historical Archive for:

  • Legal compliance (e.g., holding records for 7+ years).
  • Pension and retirement audits.
  • Detailed historical payroll results.

3. Business Process Customizations and Pain Points:

Moving from a current HCM system to SAP SuccessFactors requires a clear-eyed look at your current "technical debt." The goal is to move away from customizations toward Standard Best Practices to enable easier upgrades and reduce maintenance. Here is a structured framework to help you inventory and analyze your current state.

3.1 HCM Customization Inventory:

Document all customizations in the current system and map each to its corresponding SAP SuccessFactors configuration. The System Integrator (SI) SMEs can provide detailed insights and recommendations on how these customizations can be redesigned , implemented in the SuccessFactors HCM

3.2 Gap Analysis: Legacy vs. SuccessFactors:

The "Gap" indicates whether the requirement is truly unique or simply a limitation of your old system. I have seen building a custom solution in the current state as the only way to support specific requirements due to the system's technological limitations.

  • Standard Configuration: Can this be done using SuccessFactors‚Äô "MDF" (Metadata Framework) or Business Rules without custom code?
  • Process Alignment: Does SuccessFactors offer a "Best Practice" way to do this that is actually better than the custom way?
  • Retirement: Is this customization for a process that no longer exists or is no longer valuable?

3.3 Reporting & Data Accessibility

If you can‚Äôt get data out, the system is just a "black box."

  • Shadow Systems: Are departments keeping their own Excel trackers because the HCM reports are "unusable"?
  • Data Silos: Does your custom script prevent data from flowing into your payroll or ERP system?
  • The "Report Request" Queue: If it takes days for an analyst to build a custom SQL query for a simple headcount report, the current state is failing the business.

4. Integrations Assessment: 

Understanding the current state of the HCM integration landscape is critical and focus on the following items. 

  1. Integrations Inventory: List down the current state integrations list with source and target system details
  2. Technical Integration Landscape: Get the current state of the Integration landscape diagram; if not available, create one. This will provide a high-level view that makes the systems involved easy to understand.
  3. Integration Patterns: Get info on how current integrations are built and what type of integration patterns are used. This will help
  4. Integration tools: Understand what integration tools are used in the current landscape ( ABAP Programs, SAP PI/PO, Boomi, MuleSoft, Manual files extract, etc)
  5. Pain Points: Documenting current state integration pain points will help to address in the future state, like data not available in near time, no better visibility of data and integration points, etc. 

Integrations are one of the high-effort items in SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation projects. Having all the above information will help define the integration deployment strategy, effort, and disposition approach.

PS: Never underestimate the integration effort. 

 5. Data Migration Assessment: 

Understanding where data resides in the current state is critical to a successful implementation. Typically, Foundation, Organizational, and Employee data are migrated to SAP SuccessFactors HCM ‚Äì Employee Central. However, based on business requirements, data from additional SuccessFactors modules‚Äîsuch as performance ratings, open job requisitions, and candidate profiles‚Äîmay also be included in the migration scope.

  • Where data currently sits
  • How clean is the data
  • Categories of data
  • Employee volume- country-wise
  • Country-specific requirements

Current state HCM Assessment Outcomes :

A thorough analysis of the current HCM system is essential from both the customer and Implementation Partner perspectives to accurately scope and plan the implementation. Once detailed information is gathered, it enables the team to:

  1. Define the project scope and overall complexity
  2. Establish realistic and achievable project timelines
  3. Select and align the appropriate deployment strategy
  4. Identify opportunities to redesign and optimize business processes
  5. Highlight key transformation areas to drive business value
  6. Assess and address existing technical debt

entry.title: Reporting the latest effective date of Job Information field leveraging EC Configuration
entry.content:
Introduction

Customers frequently request reports that show the most recent data point of a certain field in Job information. The Job information object is effective dated, and the effective date is not necessarily tied to a particular field when a new event record is created.

The report administrator can create manual change report logic built into the report (Link). However, that logic pulls only the employees with changes and excludes employees whose record haven‚Äôt changed within the selected date range or since the hire event.  

Customers can leverage Employee Central (EC) configuration to support reporting data points. If a new customer is implementing EC, the latest effective date fields should be considered as requirements during EC implementation. For existing customers, this blog can be shared with the system administrator to create a new custom field if the custom fields limit hasn't been reached.

Solution

Steps are shown below. 

  1. Create a custom date field in Manage Business Configuration, in Jobinfo (or wherever it applies). Please note this is an example; you can create the custom fields for other business needs, such as Job code change date. In this case, we‚Äôre creating the latest Job title effective date so create a date field in Jobinfo. We label it ‚ÄòTest Change date‚Äô to identify the  latest Job title effective date.

2. Add permission for the custom field. 

3. Create a business rule (Configure Business Rule)

Trigger OnChange of Job title rules for HRIS Elements

4. Go back to Manage Business Configuration > Jobinfo > Find the field (Job Title) > Detail > and add the rule in Trigger Rule section.

 

5. Once the change record is entered, (in this case, the change of ‚ÄòJob title‚Äô), the custom field, ‚ÄòTest Change date‚Äô will be updated.

6. Create a Story report. In the Job Information table, 'Test Change date' is visible. 

7. Consider applying a hiring rule for the newly hired employees in the future, to set their custom field date to be hire date, following rule is needed. (Otherwise, the ‚ÄòTest Change date‚Äô field will be null until a Job title change occurs.)

Add this rule to ‚ÄòOnSave‚Äô of EmploymentInfo in BCUI > Trigger Rules.

 

Conclusion

In sum, Reporting can provide data from the system and bridge the information through reporting functions and logic. However, depending on the business requirements, reporting may require data points that must be supported by configuration. The blog shows one example of incorporating Employee Central configuration to complement reporting.

entry.title: Utilizing Employee Central Quick Actions to support Internal hires with Onboarding
entry.content:
In this article we will discuss a specific requirement from a customer for their internal moves within the same legal entity and whether onboarding is needed to deliver the desired business results.

In this specific scenario an employee moves within the same legal entity.  The customer would like the employee to check that their home address is accurate, they do not need to sign any new forms, nor do they need any onboarding tasks completed.  The customer thought they should configure the following.

  1. Onboarding for internal hires is initiated from SuccessFactors Recruitment.
  2. The SuccessFactors Employee Central record is updated based on the data from SuccessFactors Recruitment. 
  3. The system will trigger an 'Onboarding process' for the employee to check their data via 'Personal Data Collection'.

This is a perfectly valid process, but as the customer only wants to check the address, is this the best option?  A potential downside of this process is that unless the employee completes the process the onboarding task will remain open on the onboarding dashboard, and it is a rather complex solution to a basic requirement.  An alternative is as follows. When the SuccessFactors Employee Central record is updated, Employee Central sends an employee a custom email or alert that could say something like this.

Dear employee

As you now have a new position in the organisation, we would like you to double check that your home address is still correct.  The first line of your address in the system is ‚ÄòXXXX‚Äô, if this is still correct then you do not need to do anything else.

If the address is incorrect then please log into the system and click on the ‚ÄòManage My Data‚Äô icon and click on ‚ÄòChange Address‚Äô

Many Thanks

This is what it looks like in SuccessFactors Employee Central

 

This process utilizes the 'quick action cards' and means that we are not using onboarding for this process.  All workflow and permissions are respected when they make an update.

If the requirement also needed some onboarding tasks, you could still trigger this process and have onboarding tasks created via onboarding.  However, if you want the employee to sign documents then you would clearly utilize a full onboarding process.

Hopefully this article provides an insight into the potential flexibility of SuccessFactors Onboarding & Employee Central for certain internal hires scenarios.

entry.title: Hide Generic Object Values in a Dropdown field on a MDF Object
entry.content:
(or Restricting MDF Values in Drop-down Based on Target Population)

Ouf! What a complicated title for my first blog of the year. Don‚Äôt worry though, the functionality itself is much simpler than the name of this post and understanding it helps solve a requirement that is quite common.

Common use case: Can you hide the ‚ÄúCheck‚Äù payment method value in the payment information portlet for population X?

Yes, it is possible! Again, I‚Äôll use my favorite portlet (Payment Information üòÑ!) for illustrating the solution, but keep in mind that this solution is not limited to Payment Information. It applies to any Generic Object (GO) field on an MDF object, as long as the MDF object is secured via RBP.

Default Behavior

But, before I tell you the solution (it is really a quick fix!), let‚Äôs understand the usual default behavior:

 

Let‚Äôs look at the Payment Method field in the Payment Information portlet. It is a Generic Object field type.

As shown, no explicit permission is required on the Payment Method object for its values to appear in the field drop-down, they are visible by default. However, if you click on the object Quick Card, you‚Äôll receive an error indicating that you are not authorized to view the Payment Method details.

Once you grant View permission on the Payment Method object, users can click the Quick Card and view the related Payment Method information.

Finally, if you restrict the Payment Method object using target criteria in the permission role assignment (after granting View permission), users will still see all the values possible in the drop-down but only be able to access the Quick Card for the Payment Methods that match the defined criteria.

 

So, what‚Äôs the solution?

It actually comes down to flipping a single switch in Provisioning, one that isn‚Äôt widely known (hence this blog). The setting is called ‚ÄúEnable RBP Target Criteria for Value Help (Only with data type: Generic Object)‚Äù. Once enabled, it unlocks the ability to filter Generic Object in drop-down fields.

 

If you turn on the switch in provisioning: Enable RBP Target Criteria for Value Help (Only with data type: Generic Object)

By default, if you do not have View permission on the object, the field will display ‚ÄúNo Data.‚Äù

Granting View permission to Payment Method object provides access to all available drop-down values. Users can also click the Quick Card to view the related Payment Method details.

Finally, if you restrict the Payment Method object using target criteria in the permission role assignment (after granting View permission), users will only see the values defined in the restrict criteria!

Solving our requirements!

 

 

Implication

The considerations outlined mainly apply to already‚Äëlive systems. In those environments, historical RBP configurations may have been built around the previous behavior‚Äîwhere values appeared in drop‚Äëdown lists even without explicit View permission on the target object. So, if you are already Live, enabling this setting does come with implications. If you‚Äôre considering turning this on in an existing environment, you‚Äôll need to revisit and validate your current Role-Based Permission (RBP) configuration. In particular, make sure that any secured MDF objects used as fields in your active MDF objects are explicitly set to View. As shown earlier, when the switch is disabled, users can still see values in the drop-down even without View permission on the target object. However, once you enable ‚ÄúEnable RBP Target Criteria for Value Help‚Äù, the system starts enforcing RBP strictly and the drop-down will display No Data.

Second, enabling this switch requires granting View access at the object level. This has an additional side effect: users will now be able to click the Quick Card and view the details of the related object. If you do not want users to see all fields displayed in the Quick Card, you must further restrict access by configuring Field-Level Overrides. This allows you to expose only the necessary fields while keeping sensitive information hidden‚Äîeven though object-level View permission is enabled. Here is how you come to hide the fields in Manage Permission Roles:

For a net-new (greenfield) implementation, enabling ‚ÄúEnable RBP Target Criteria for Value Help‚Äù from the outset generally poses no issue. However, it‚Äôs important to be aware that this approach may require more Field-Level Overrides than usual, which can translate into additional configuration effort. In greenfield projects, RBP is designed as an integral part of the implementation, making it easier to align permissions with the desired data visibility from day one. Because the permission model is built upfront, enabling this setting provides greater long-term flexibility - particularly the ability to control whether dropdown values are hidden or displayed for Generic field types on MDF objects as requirements evolve.

Conclusion

Small setting‚Äîbig impact üòõ

So, there is a simple way to hide Generic Object values in MDF drop-downs, and yes, it really does come down to a single switch in Provisioning called ‚ÄúEnable RBP Target Criteria for Value Help‚Äù.

For net-new projects, turning it on from the start is a solid and flexible approach for requirements (like the payment method one!). For existing systems, it may require some RBP alignment, but nothing unexpected now, you know what you need to do!

And if this blog saved you some troubleshooting time, don‚Äôt forget to leave a Kudo at the top ‚Äî it‚Äôs always appreciated üòä

entry.title: Simple MCP server setup for comparing Successfactors configurations across Instances
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • UseCase
  • Pre-requisites
  • MCP server development in VS code
  • Install MCP server in Claude
  • Demo Screenshots
  • Conclusion

 

 

Introduction

Model Context Protocol ( MCP)  has made quite a significant  impact on how data from the different solutions are accessed by the AI assistants or agents.  The layer to expose data from solutions have been decoupled completely from the AI assistants.

To summarise MCP -- Its a standard protocol which is understood by all AI Agents. Once  the data is registered or exposed in a MCP server , any of the AI assistants can effectively  access the data and proceed with the next steps as requested by the users.

AI assistants with MCP servers setup for a hybrid SAP Successfactors (SAP SF)suite would be able to handle a lot of usecases which requires a significant development in the traditional world.

Setup Overview

SAP SF  and on prem SAP HCM odata services can be registered as an MCP server which  can be deployed in SAP BTP platform , The MCP servers then be installed in  one of the AI assistants used by the organisations.  With this setup , it is possible to handle the below use cases  wherein once data is available , the AI assistants do the heavy lifting of processing data with LLMs

  • Compare configurations between different SAP SF instances 
  • Compare data between SAP SF and on prem 
  • Update data across SAP SF and on prem
  • Automatic updation of workbooks
  • Analyse data from SAP SF  and create dashboards
  • Create reports combing data from both SAP SF and SAP HCM payroll systems
  • And Many more

UseCase

For the blog, i would like to take a very simple use case of comparing configurations across SAP SF instances ( dev and quality or quality and production)  and develop a quick POC by leveraging the usage of MCP servers and AI assistants.

With SAP SF Configuration Transport Center,  we need to include all the modified objects manually into the Bundle and  there are possibilities of missing out moving  certain configurations  to productive instance which would result in the processes to fail.

By comparing configurations across instances --we ensure that all configs are in sync and the risk of process failing due to misconfigurations are minimized.

 

Spoiler
As this is a POC  --I  have taken so called cinematic liberty of hardcoding the credentials directly in the codebase which would/should never been done in productive environment.  Destination services of platform where the MCP server is deployed  should be used  for authentication for prod environments
Spoiler
For the POC --  the MCP server is a local server VS code and i used Claude Desktop version as an AI assistant which is free for the requirements of the POC

Pre-requisites

  • Install Claude Desktop  -- free version is enough for the POC 
  • VS code for development
  • MCP SDK  -->https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk
    • I  have used python SDK and installed the relevant python packages like "uv" as mentioned in the link above
  • Finally -- API access to atleast 2 SAP SF tenants which can be compared

MCP server development in VS code

Open the folder in VScode and run the below command in the terminal to enable the selected folder as a uv managed folder

uv init .

Add MCP dependancies with the below command in the terminal

uv add "mcp[cli]"

Once the dependancies are added , the project structure in VS code looks as below

Following is the code snippet to be included in main.py folder.

The logic is very straight forward and simple wherein we first initialize the MCP server.

We include the MCP tool via the annotation and define the function  with the name of instance and  name of the entity as an argument. The name of instance and entity name would be passed from the AI assistant to the MCP server during runtime.

The standard SAP SF metadata api url is defined in the function and using the 'requests' package, a GET call is implemented.

As the response would be xml, the python package 'xmltodict' is used to convert the xml data to json response which is then returned back.

# main.py

from typing import Any
from mcp.server.fastmcp import FastMCP
import requests
import xmltodict

#Init Server
mcp = FastMCP("SFgetConfig", dependencies=["requests","xmltodict"])

@mcp.tool()
def get_configuration(instance: str , entity: str ) -> dict[str, Any]:
    """Get Configuration metadata details for the entity within the instance"""
    username= f"<username>@{instance}"    
    password = "<password>"
    apiUrl = f"https://api12preview.sapsf.eu/odata/v2/{entity}/$metadata"
    credentials = (username, password)
    
    meta_response = requests.get(apiUrl, auth=credentials)

    meta_json = xmltodict.parse(meta_response.text.encode("UTF-8"))

    return meta_json



    
if __name__ == "__main__":
    mcp.run()

To test the server locally execute the following command in the terminal window

uv run mcp dev main.py

This would open up a local host as below wherein the mcp inspector is launched

 

Click on Connect button and then select Tools which will list out all the tools that has been defined.

Select the tool 'get_configuration' , provide the arguments, press 'Run Tool' and test if the response is successful.

 

 

This implies that the MCP server is able to make an API call to SF instance and retrieve the respective metdata.

 

Install MCP server in Claude

Run the below command in terminal to install the MCP server with Claud configuration file.

uv run mcp install main.py

To validate, open Claude  and select File -->Settings

Navigate to the section 'Developer' and select 'Edit Config'

The claude configuration file should display the MCP server that we installed from VScode and also previously installed servers

The MCP servers are also visible in the connector sections in the  prompt window .

Now Claude is all set to interact with SAP Successfactors instance via the MCP server installed within its configuration

Demo Screenshots
